üìä Brazil‚Äôs Largest Bank Recommends Bitcoin as a Portfolio Hedge

Brazil‚Äôs largest private bank, Ita√∫ Unibanco, is advising investors to allocate 1%‚Äì3% of their portfolios to  $BTC, framing it as a diversification tool rather than a speculative bet.

According to Renato Eid, head of beta strategies at Ita√∫ Asset Management, Bitcoin should serve as a complementary asset, not a core holding. The focus is on long-term positioning, not market timing, with  $BTC offering returns that are largely uncorrelated with domestic economic cycles.

The recommendation is closely tied to currency risk. After the Brazilian real hit record lows in late 2024, Ita√∫ highlighted Bitcoin‚Äôs potential role as a partial hedge against FX volatility, alongside its function as a global store of value.

Ita√∫‚Äôs guidance references BITI11, a Brazil-listed Bitcoin ETF launched in partnership with Galaxy Digital. The fund currently manages over $115 million, providing local investors with regulated BTC exposure and international diversification.

The move reflects a broader institutional shift. Similar allocation ranges have been suggested by global banks, signaling that Bitcoin is increasingly viewed not as an outlier, but as a structured portfolio component in emerging-market risk management.

Bitcoin distribution by long-term holders has reached one of the largest levels seen over the past five years.

With ETF flows turning negative and overall market demand softening, supply-side pressure is becoming more visible.

That said, this does not necessarily indicate full-scale capitulation.
It can also be read as coins accumulated at higher levels rotating into the hands of the next group of holders.

What matters most is who is absorbing this supply, and at which price levels.
The market is now in a phase of supply‚Äìdemand reorganization.

BTC inflows to Binance have surged.

Spikes like this are often driven less by spot selling and more by:
‚Ä¢ collateral being posted
‚Ä¢ futures position adjustments
‚Ä¢ liquidity preparation ahead of sharp moves

The key point is that inflows do not automatically mean an immediate price drop.
In many cases, they appear as a preparation phase before a larger move.

Focus on flows, not just price.
The market is positioning for its next move.

First, a Bank of Japan policy decision should not be mechanically translated into
‚Äúrate hike = an immediate 20‚Äì30% crash in BTC.‚Äù

There have been periods in the past when declines overlapped with BOJ tightening, but those moves were driven by a combination of factors:
‚Ä¢ global liquidity conditions
‚Ä¢ relative dynamics versus U.S. dollar rates
‚Ä¢ the scale and unwind of the yen carry trade

This time as well, what matters most is not the size of the rate hike itself, but how much the market has already priced in.

Volatility may rise, but this is not a moment to position based on fear.
It‚Äôs a day to stay calm and focus on flows and supply‚Äìdemand dynamics.

Since the broader selloff began in mid-November, Bitcoin whale buying has actually strengthened rather than weakened.

There have been brief periods where holdings dipped slightly, but those moves are negligible compared with the scale of accumulated buying so far.

While price continues to move lower, whale BTC holdings are steadily increasing.

Surface-level price action does not always align with what capital is doing beneath the surface.
What‚Äôs happening now is quiet accumulation.

QUANTUM FEARS RESURFACE AS ADAM BACK DISMISSES NEAR TERM THREAT TO BITCOIN

- Adam Back says Bitcoin should be quantum ready, but real threats remain decades away.

- He argues current quantum computing research remains early, fragile, and far from breaking Bitcoin security.

- Back predicts no meaningful quantum risk to Bitcoin emerging within the next ten years. Even partial cryptography failures would not allow network wide theft, since Bitcoin security is not encryption dependent.

CLAIMS AND COUNTERCLAIMS

- The debate intensified after claims that advanced quantum machines could arrive far sooner.

- Venture investor Chamath Palihapitiya suggested cryptographically relevant systems might appear within two to five years.

- Back rejected that timeline, citing quantum resistant standards and long upgrade paths already available.

- He says Bitcoin has ample time to upgrade before any practical quantum computer exists.

MARKET REACTION

- Market anxiety persists, with some executives warning quantum fears are already slowing capital inflows.

- Others argue larger risks come from regulation, legal pressure, and government influence on infrastructure.

- For now, Back maintains quantum computing may strengthen Bitcoin resilience rather than threaten its survival.

Bank of Japan interest rate  On Dec 19, 2025, the BoJ hiked rates by 25 bps to 0.75%, the highest level in 30 years.    This marked a clear break from decades of ultra-loose policy as inflation stayed above the 2% target for over 3 years.    Governor Ueda stressed the move is part of gradual normalization, with real rates still negative. But the message was clear: cheap yen is slowly disappearing.    Why this matters for cryptoüëá    Japan has long fueled global risk assets through the yen carry trade.  Investors borrowed yen at near-zero rates, converted to USD, and deployed capital into stocks and crypto.    Rate hikes flip that trade: ‚Ä¢ Borrowing costs rise ‚Ä¢ Yen strengthens ‚Ä¢ Carry trades unwind ‚Ä¢ Risk assets get sold to repay yen loans    Crypto often takes the hit first due to leverage and 24/7 liquidity.    üìâ History tells the story Mar 2024 hike ‚Üí BTC dropped ~22%  Jul 2024 hike ‚Üí BTC fell to $49K, $600B wiped from total crypto cap  Jan 2025 hike ‚Üí BTC slid 20‚Äì30% in a prolonged downtrend   Even in Dec 2025, rising hike odds alone may pushed $BTC  down 5%.    üìä Japan‚Äôs bond market is already flashing stress 10Y yields near 1.87%, highest since 2008, signaling the real end of cheap yen funding.    Bottom line: BoJ hikes don‚Äôt just impact Japan. They drain global liquidity. And when leverage dries up, crypto usually feels it first.  Risk assets should stay alert.  #BTC Price Analysis#

Many question whether the AI boom is just another bubble. I strongly disagree. What we are seeing is a structural shift, not a temporary hype. AI is becoming a foundational layer across technology, industry, healthcare, defense, and government. Every major economy is investing heavily because falling behind means losing long-term competitiveness. This makes AI investment unavoidable.

Geopolitical realities reinforce this trend. Global defense spending is rising, and priorities such as security, infrastructure, and technological independence are firmly back on the agenda. These are long-term drivers, not short-term noise. Future reconstruction efforts, including post-war rebuilding, could further support global growth.

I am also positive on crypto. While still seen as risky, adoption is increasing, regulation is improving, and the technology is maturing. Recent market corrections of over 20% have created opportunities. Looking ahead, 2026 could mark new highs. Overall, I remain calm, disciplined, and optimistic about the long-term market outlook.

Assets tied to scaling, interoperability, and high throughput are seeing renewed spot demand as on-chain activity picks up. Structure Still Intact On the 4H timeframe, BTC continues to defend a key demand zone and ascending structure despite multiple tests. Bank of Japan Raises Rates - $BTC Market Reacts Higher


The Bank of Japan raised its policy rate to 0.75%. Formally, this is negative for risk assets - yet the market moved higher. The reason is simple: the hike was fully priced in, with markets assigning a ~98% probability to this outcome. What really mattered wasn‚Äôt the decision itself, but the tone.


The BOJ Governor signaled that further tightening will continue - but very slowly and cautiously.


This eased fears of an abrupt unwinding of the yen carry trade, where cheap yen funding is deployed into higher-yielding assets, including crypto.


Earlier in December, many expected a BOJ hike to push $BTCbelow $70k due to liquidity tightening. Instead, the market did the opposite - the negative was absorbed in advance.


The takeaway remains unchanged: liquidity and expectations matter far more than the headline decisions of central banks.

$BTC  Why the Next Fed QE Could Break the 4-Year Crypto Cycle  There are increasing signs that the Federal Reserve is moving closer to a new phase of quantitative easing (QE), or at least to a liquidity-expanding regime that closely resembles it. After ending Quantitative Tightening and slowing balance sheet reduction, the Fed has already started injecting liquidity through Treasury bill purchases and repo facilities. While not officially labeled as QE, these actions effectively increase system liquidity.  At the same time, interest rates are expected to trend lower over the coming quarters due to slowing economic growth and rising financial stress. Historically, every major crypto bull market has coincided with periods of expansionary monetary policy, not simply with Bitcoin‚Äôs halving schedule.  This is why the traditional 4-year crypto cycle may no longer hold.  The cycle worked in the past because halvings happened within predictable liquidity regimes. Today, macro liquidity is the dominant driver. If the Fed resumes QE‚Äîor even sustained balance sheet expansion‚Äîrisk assets like Bitcoin and crypto could enter a prolonged bull phase independent of the halving cycle.  In other words, crypto may be transitioning from a mechanically driven cycle to a liquidity-driven market, where central bank policy matters more than calendar-based narratives. If that‚Äôs the case, the next major crypto move may arrive earlier, last longer, and look structurally different from previous cycles.

Bank of Japan Raises Rates - $BTC Market Reacts Higher


The Bank of Japan raised its policy rate to 0.75%. Formally, this is negative for risk assets - yet the market moved higher. The reason is simple: the hike was fully priced in, with markets assigning a ~98% probability to this outcome. What really mattered wasn‚Äôt the decision itself, but the tone.


The BOJ Governor signaled that further tightening will continue - but very slowly and cautiously.


This eased fears of an abrupt unwinding of the yen carry trade, where cheap yen funding is deployed into higher-yielding assets, including crypto.


Earlier in December, many expected a BOJ hike to push $BTCbelow $70k due to liquidity tightening. Instead, the market did the opposite - the negative was absorbed in advance.


The takeaway remains unchanged: liquidity and expectations matter far more than the headline decisions of central banks.

$BTC BREAKING: $7.1 trillion worth of US stock and ETF options expire today, the largest triple-witching event ever.

Triple witching is a quarterly market event that happens four times a year, on the third Friday of March, June, September, and December.

On this day, three types of derivatives expire at the same time:
Stock options, index options, index futures

Across the last 14 triple witching events, the S&P 500 averaged around -0.5% on the day.

Bitcoin has historically ranged between 6%-9% around triple witching periods, with sharp short term swings followed by stabilization once expiry pressure clears.

Expect volatility today as well.
